title: Death at St. Mercy Hospital
setting: Dr. Eleanor Voss, chief of cardiology at St. Mercy Hospital, was found dead in her office Monday morning. She was last seen alive at 8:00 PM Sunday evening during her overnight shift. Security footage shows no one entering or leaving the building between 11:00 PM and 5:00 AM — meaning the killer was already inside.

answer.reasoning: Dr. Blake was the only person with access to Room 401 at 9:30 PM. The syringe found in the sharps container on Floor 4 contained potassium chloride residue. Dr. Blake's keycard accessed Floor 4 at 9:25 PM despite claiming to be in the ER. Nurse Patel saw someone in a white coat near Room 401 at 9:30 PM. Dr. Blake had motive: Dr. Voss discovered he was falsifying clinical trial data and planned to report him Monday morning.

dr_blake.name: Dr. Raymond Blake
dr_blake.motive: Dr. Voss discovered he was falsifying data in a major clinical trial. She confronted him Sunday afternoon and told him she would report him to the medical board Monday morning. His career, reputation, and freedom were at stake.
dr_blake.statement: I was in the ER all evening covering for Dr. Santos who called in sick. I didn't go above the second floor all night. I heard about Dr. Voss this morning and I'm devastated — she was my mentor.

nurse_chen.name: Nurse Margaret Chen
nurse_chen.motive: Dr. Voss had filed a formal complaint about medication errors on Chen's shifts. Chen was facing a disciplinary hearing next week that could end her 20-year career.
nurse_chen.statement: I was on the ICU floor (Floor 3) all night. I took my break at 9:00 PM in the third-floor break room and was back on the floor by 9:20 PM. I never went to Floor 4.

dr_santos.name: Dr. Maria Santos
dr_santos.motive: Dr. Voss blocked her promotion to department head last year, citing 'lack of leadership qualities.' Santos was still angry about it.
dr_santos.statement: I called in sick Sunday but came back to the hospital around 8:30 PM because I forgot my laptop in my office on Floor 2. I grabbed it and left by 9:15 PM. The front desk can confirm I signed out.

orderly_james.name: Victor James
orderly_james.motive: Dr. Voss caught him stealing controlled substances from the pharmacy last month. She gave him a 'last chance' warning instead of reporting him, but he lived in fear she'd change her mind.
orderly_james.statement: I was doing my rounds — moving equipment, restocking supply closets. I was on Floor 1 from 8:00 to 9:00, Floor 2 from 9:00 to 10:00, and Floor 3 from 10:00 to 11:00. I never went to Floor 4 on Sunday night.

physical_evidence: Syringe found in sharps container on Floor 4 — contains potassium chloride residue, wiped clean of fingerprints
Dr. Voss's office door was unlocked when found — she always locked it when working alone
Dr. Voss's computer shows she was drafting an email to the medical board about 'falsified trial data' at 9:15 PM — the email was never sent
Security camera on Floor 4 was 'undergoing maintenance' Sunday — no footage available
Dr. Blake's lab coat found in the Floor 4 laundry bin Monday morning, though he claims he never went to Floor 4

witness_statements.statement: Dr. Santos signed in at 8:30 PM and signed out at 9:10 PM. No one else signed in or out between 8 PM and 11 PM.
I saw someone in a white coat near Room 401 around 9:30 PM. I assumed it was Dr. Voss's colleague visiting. I didn't see their face clearly.
Dr. Blake was in the ER with me most of the evening, but he stepped out for about 25 minutes sometime after 9 PM. He said he went to get coffee.
The cafeteria closed at 8 PM Sunday. No one came for coffee after closing.

syringe.description: Medical syringe with potassium chloride residue, found in Floor 4 sharps container
syringe.availability: Available in supply closets on every floor; potassium chloride stored in Floor 3 pharmacy
syringe.notes: Wiped clean of fingerprints. Potassium chloride in sufficient dose causes cardiac arrest — nearly undetectable without targeted toxicology.

scalpel.availability: Available in surgical suites (Floor 2) and research lab (Floor 4)
scalpel.notes: No scalpels found out of place. Victim showed no cuts or lacerations.

medication.availability: Pharmacy on Floor 3, locked cabinet requiring authorized access
medication.notes: Toxicology showed no oral medications beyond Dr. Voss's normal prescriptions. Pharmacy inventory matches records.

blunt_object.notes: No signs of blunt force trauma on the victim. Cause of death was chemical, not physical.

rules: The killer must have had physical access to Floor 4 around the time of death (9:00-10:00 PM).
The weapon must match the cause of death (lethal injection of potassium chloride).
Keycard logs cannot be faked — they are tamper-proof hardware records.
Each suspect's statement may contain lies, but witness observations and physical evidence do not lie.
The killer is one of the four suspects listed.
